Description: Lower body sherd of possibly Ionian black-figured pottery cup with top of stem; interior, from outside: black area; band of lotus buds between dilute lines; in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of part of lion to right (most of head, neck with added red on mane, body with red under belly and on rump, and tail remaining); exterior glazed black with single reserved band. Micaceous red-brown clay.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The decorative motif finds parallels with South Ionian Little Master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Schlotzhauer Type 9C. Type 9C cups correspond to Attic Siana, band and Gordion cups. Details of technique can be found on Euboean and Boeotian imitations of Attic work. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are rare at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GO.736) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
